Sairento est une expérience VR très intéressante et diablement jouissive une fois le jeu bien pris en main.

Vous aurez à déambuler dans des arènes et/ou des séries de couloirs et salles afin d'éliminer tous les ennemis sur votre passage. Pour cela un large éventail d'armes sera mis à votre disposition tel que des pistolets, fusil à pompe, fusil d'assaut, pistolet mitrailleur, arc, kunai, shuriken, sabre/katana... et vous pourrez en equiper 5 selon vos choix afin de correspondre au mieux à votre type de gameplay et également selon l'approche.

Les points forts:
- Des mouvements variés: comme des jumps, double jumps, glissade, wall run, wall jump... tout ce qu'il faut pour vous mettre dans la peau d'un véritable cyber ninja et avec grande classe.
- un système de customisation de l'armement et de perks: oui, car en plus de choisir son equipement vous aurez un systeme de loot vous faisant gagner en efficacité et puissance apportant constament une sensation de progression. Les perks eux vous apporteront encore plus de puissance en débloquants des skills pouvant modifier votre approche dans les niveau comme voir les ennemis à travers les murs à une certaine distance, pouvant anticiper et plannifier une approche pour un kill furtif !
- De la rejouabilité: les niveaux étant relativement courts, ce sera avec plaisir que d'enchainer les missions pour obtenir toujours plus de puissance et être une véritable machine à tuer. 5 niveaux de difficultés avec possibilité, selon une devise à collecter en jeu, d'ajouter des handicaps mais qui vous récompenseront d'avantage dans les loots. Certains niveaux sont classés "challenge" et vous demanderont de ne pas perdre la moindre vie sous peine d'être aussitôt expulsé par l'echec...
- Pas testé, mais un mode coop est disponible.

Points faible:
- Graphiquement le jeu est pas moche sans être exceptionnel, mais pour le faire tourner à fond avec un super echantillonage à 2.0 de façon très fluide, il va falloir une très bonne machine.
- Il y a pas mal de bugs de collision avec les décors, il arrive souvent de traverser des éléments décoratif au point de passer au travers des murs et tomber dans le vide (hors zone de jeu). Pas de panique pour autant, vous ne mourrez pas et le jeu vous téléportera de nouveau dans la zone de jeu. Dommage que ca casse le rythme lors des combats, étant en accès anticipé ca reste pardonnable, en espérant que ce soit corrigé.  Si toutefois vous jouez en déplacement par téléportation, vous ne devriez pas avoir de problèmes.


Conclusion: 
Sairento est une excellente expérience à vivre en VR, loin d'être parfait et avec une réalisation parfois un peu bancale sans pour autant plomber le plaisir, il sera un jeu de choix dans votre bibliothèque Steam que vous soyez possesseur d'un Vive ou d'un Oculus.

Note: au moment de cette évaluation, la campagne solo n'est pas disponible, mais sachez qu'il y en à une de prévue et qu'elle devrait arriver dans peu de temps.

I'll get right into it.
I'd never heard of this title but I was looking for VR games (during the sales) and this was part of a bundle which graphically looked nice, but I figured there would be a trade off... and there is, I'll come back to that.
I've been burned by Early Access before too but I figured VR is still finding its ground, so took the chance - I'm glad I did!

The graphics, are stunning especially for a VR title, most developers seem to think the allure of VR means that we don't mind travelling back to the 80's for graphics... This game presents like pretty much any recent FPS out there but then immerses you in the action.

The controls are natural and slick, You can have weapons on your shoulders (reach back and grab), on your waist (grab at belt holster level) and then one more weapon on your lower back (reach to the small of your back and grab)
Reloading is done by simply flicking the gun up and down - this seems pretty responsive though and I haven't accidentally reloaded... yet!
Although sometimes when I'm in a panic fight, I have accidentally put away a sword or swapped to a gun - this is more me than the game though, I think!

Movement is done in a really nice way, its the normal press, select, release but it doesn't continue or freeze the action, it slows it down - Which means enemies moving at high speed are still coming for you, as are projectiles etc. There are plenty of configurable options for the movement too but if you go for the full movement option, jumps and bouncing off walls can be a bit disorientating at first but rapidly you get used to it and again it becomes natural.

Gameplay is great, you have various guns, projectiles, swords and a bow to choose from so you'll find something that suits your personal way of playing. There is character progression and weapon/armour progression too - so the more you play you can activate new traits and upgrade your weapons and armour. 

The trade off...
Its Early Access, so sometimes things can glitch, I've seen a Sumo lose all interest in me and ram a wall, and stay doing that until I put him out of his misery... I've fell through the scenery and made it back into the game... I've also fell through the scenery and watched it disappear into the abyss above while I plunge never endingly into the cityscape.
I'm sure with a bit of effort you could break your game too and there doesn't seem to be a clean way to get back to the menu system, so its just a case of crashing out and starting again.
Ocassionally I've seen my sword be the wrong way around blade facing in, handle facing out, which renders it quite useless, but this is remedied by resheathing and unsheathing it.

Even with those flaws (which I'm sure will be ironed out) I'd highly recommend this game, I've only played single player so far, but I'm looking forward to Co-oping it with friends and of course the forthcoming campaigns

As a bit of background..
I've been waiting for games to come that peaked my interest in VR.
When the Vive came with Fallout VR and Doom VR (Two of my fave series) it became a must have for me...
Sadly both of those games didn't quite do it for me - They're great but I think movement in VR is something that is still Very much under development whereas these guys seem to have gotten it just right for this game.

在《默者 VR》这款游戏中中，我们可以扮演的角色可以双手同时持武器作战，甚至还可以混搭武士刀与现代枪械进行战斗。这种同时使用冷热兵器的设定，提升了玩家的战斗体验，让原本单一的远近程攻击方式，变成了可以随心所欲根据自己喜好而改变的战斗风格。
　　这种使用远近武器的攻击方式在游戏中得到很好地平衡。因为玩家在场景中瞬移和跳跃都会消耗自身体力，当体力耗尽时会不能移动，一定要等待体力恢复才行再次移动。而在恢复体力间隙，就只能使用伤害数较低的枪械远程瞄准射击敌人。
　　而武士刀因为可以做到一刀秒杀敌人，在有体力的情况下玩家可以配合着瞬移和跳跃快速接近敌人，挥舞武士刀直接秒杀敌人。武士刀近身的爽快战斗感是枪械这些热兵器所不能媲美的，而枪械远程便捷的特性也是武士刀不能取代的。
值得一提的是，游戏的物理引擎支持玩家挡刀挡子弹。因为游戏中敌人分为远近攻击两种敌人，玩家能够用武士刀抵挡敌人的挥刀和子弹，同样在后期的任务中敌人也可以做到挡刀挡子弹。这种设定提升了AI的难度，让游戏更加有挑战性，也使得玩家在战斗中的互动与沉浸感更强烈，更加投入扮演到游戏中的角色。
　 除此之外，游戏还有一个特色系统，那就是控制时间。游戏中玩家拥有放慢时间的特殊能力，在游戏中玩家可以通过放慢时间来躲避子弹，甚至在敌人数量多的情况下放慢时间从容杀光全部敌人。这种放慢时间的能力设定从游戏《马克思·佩恩》系列开始，就经常出现在游戏中。时间的元素对动作或射击游戏来说，其实也是一个很重要的元素。这种设定能够让玩家在游戏中更轻易地躲避敌人的火力，使得玩家可以更加精准地走位移动，从容地用枪械瞄准射击。尽管降低了游戏难度，但是对于玩家的体验而言来说，无非是值得的。
　　同时，放慢时间的能力让玩家更加“中二”地体验游戏，使用各种耍帅的招式动作来击杀敌人。例如跳跃到空中放慢时间来射击敌人，或者放慢时间躲避子弹，这些放慢时间所带来的镜头画面非常有动作电影的即视感，增加了游戏的沉浸感。
　　《默者 VR》加入了RPG游戏常见的元素，装备升级、技能天赋、等级提升以及宝箱掉落等RPG常见的系统功能。这些RPG元素的加入无疑让游戏的可玩性得到了进一步提升，让原本简单粗暴的动作游戏增加了角色培养的体验乐趣。　甚至，可以通过不同的天赋路线，选择双刀流、双枪流等多样化的攻击方式，使得游戏中每一次执行任务都可以有着不同的战斗体验。这样一来，通过技能天赋的升级，游戏的战斗体验也会再一次得到提升，让玩家可以更加爽快地进行战斗。而装备系统也是经典的RPG元素，玩家在场景中开宝箱或击杀敌人掉落的材料，可以强化已有的武士刀甚至是枪械，增加这些武器装备的属性，通过装备的强化让玩家变得更强大，面对难度越来越大的任务关卡，能够更加得心应手。
　　游戏的背景设定在未来的日本，所以游戏中玩家所在的场景充满了科幻风，霓虹大厦上满是写满了日文的广告牌子，同时保留了一些日本复古的建筑风格。看似日本传统房屋的内部却充满了高科技的装潢，为玩家展示了一个科技越来越发达却保留传统经典元素的未来日本。同时，游戏的背景音乐虽然是快节奏风格的音乐，但还是能听出其中融入的日本乐器的元素。当玩家执行任务不同时，背景音乐也会随之变化，营造了一个充满紧张刺激的游戏氛围。游戏中的各种音效表现也十分到位，武士刀、枪械，甚至是放慢时间时的音效都专门处理，真实的音效表现更有代入感。
　　总得来说，《默者 VR》作为“抢先体验”状态下的游戏，官方很好地将游戏的特色都展示出来。在游戏目前版本中，从画面音效的表现到游戏玩法内容，玩家已经可以体验到一个相对完整的游戏内容。

This is far and beyond my favorite VR game. Nothing else quite encapsulates the feeling of flying through the air in slow motion and putting two well-placed arrows through the heads of legitimate threats with a bow that doubles as a slice-and-dice melee weapon. Despite the powerful feelings offered by the variety of jumps, wallruns, and backflips available to you, Sairento VR does a fantastic job in balancing your own godlike abilities with swarms of bullets, homing-blades, and fellow sword-wielders who can and will kill you if you don't keep moving. Mobility is key, and not once did I feel excessively "tanky" while playing (save, that is, for when I was playing on low-tier levels and/or at a low difficulty setting).

Additionally, though I would certainly love more unique weapons to choose from, this game does supply a satisfactory amount of tools with which to slay hordes of enemies. Pistols, SMGs, assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, throwing knives, bows, and, of course, swords, with ample dual-wielding potential for almost all of these as well as "backhanding" for the swords, allowing for plenty of awesome combinations.

All in all, I could not recommend this game more, and though the price point is more than that of many VR games, it is worth every penny.

Also, for those on a Viveport subscription, the "Lite" version not only cuts content, it is a fundamentally earlier version of the game. This version is worlds ahead, and unless the core gameplay itself dissuaded you from the Lite edition, this should fix any prior qualms you had with the inferior release.

In short, this game epitomizes for me the road ahead for VR and has been my most fulfilling VR experience to date.

LOCOMOTION: A superb game that's growing sometimes by the day, no VR game has come close to Sairento's brilliant movement mechanics, allowing brilliant jumps, slides, wall runs and teleportations all with the added benefit of having bullet time at your whim and command. 

WEAPONS: A vast array of melee, projectiles and firearms allow you to personalise your specific ninja combat strategy. Specific teired relics allow further customization of how each weapon behaves and gives you a fair amount of power to tweak your loadout. Armour has a similar mechanic: eg. boots that give you an extra jump if you want to be above the fray spaying bullets down, or wall sticky boots that allow you to gain a static vantage point and snipe.

LEVELING AND FURTHER CUSTOMIZATION: Recognisable exp. leveling system opens up into a moderate skill tree that gives futher personalization of how to take on the next level.

BAD GUYS: At the moment there is a satifying amount of opponents with different skills and abilities that you face. By all accounts this is only going to grow.

GAMEPLAY: The game is intuitive and the most fun I have had with my Vive. Felt a degree of immersion and "bad-assery" like no other. Leaping into a group of Bushi's dual wielding SMG's, dodging bullets, slowing down time to draw my sword and decapitate the unlucky gunman behind me upon landing. There should be laws against this level of fun.

SINGLE PLAYER/ CO-OP ETC/ CAMPAIGN: Multiplayer is apperntly on the cards, though as of writing this it is not yet instituted, and although there is no explicit story driven campaign yet (apparently planned though), the structure of the game has kept me returning through level 1 through 100 and back to do it all again. Trying new load outs, questing for that next legendary relic, changing up my skills, all compelling reasons to revisit. 

LOCATIONS: As of writing this there are about six locations to stage your fights. Stand out ones are a huge street level with alleys and rooftops, and a train station with randomized rooms, A hall with a fun verticle dynamic. At the moment this is an area that needs to grow, as one gets a bit of fatigue revisiting the same places, but with the developers experimenting with procedural level generation, this shows great promise.

Solid 9 out of 10, with room for improvements with upcoming updates and the full release.

It has a ton of replay value with the semi-RPG elements that remind me of Borderlands and Shadow Warrior 2. You can customize your lodout with plenty of gun and melee options as well as your armor (helmet, chest, wrists, belt, and feet) and then you can augment each weapon and armor with mods, or relics. In addition to the loadout, there are three skill trees that increase your standard things like health, health regen, ammo storage for specific weapons, loot pick-up range, enemy radar, loot radar, etc... but then there's the movement and abilities that really help to turn you into a badass ninja.

What really makes Sairento stand apart from other shooters is the movement system/s. I love playing Warframe, and Sairento is basically a first-person VR version of Warframe, or at least the closest thing to it for VR right now. You can dash towards enemies, shooting at and slicing through them as you dash, or you can jump onto or over them, or you can wall-run pass or through them, you can jump and then trigger a double jump to a new direction, and you can even complete a landing of a jump with a combat slide and melee or shoot while sliding. In all of these actions, you can trigger a slow-motion effect if you want to really take your time in pulling off a solid headshot or lining up the perfect downward thrust of your blade down the spine of an enemy. Recently, they answered the requests of the player base and added touchpad locomotion, similar to what you're seen in Onward. This really, really helps with the melee allowing you to stealth a few enemies quietly before catching the attention of all the enemies.

The options are also well done. For audio, the music, effects, and UI are on their own sliders. For visuals you can increase (or decrease) the super-sampling level. Then you get into controls and there's a lot. You can pick your dominant hand, you can use a simple movement system or go to the advanced one and this is where you can control how sliding works, enable confort settings for teleportation, movement speed of the touchpad locomotion,  linking touchpad locomotion to head oe controller orientation, and much more.  They've really knocked it out of the park with giving players options and controll over their experience.

It's not perfect as the enemy variety and location variety could be improved, but it's got enough gameplay and locations so far that it's enough to give you a few hours of entertainment before you notice these things.

Sairento VR is still in early access; my thoughts may change when the game is released fully.

Sairento VR is a first-person action game where you play a futuristic ninja. There are several weapon types to use (katana, pistol, sub machinegun, assault rifle and shotgun). Currently the game is pretty barebones, but what is there is extremely promising.

You select a mission type (usually either a Survival or Elimination) and are dispatched to one of the maps. They aren't particularly diverse currently and a lot are either Eastern-themed (think futuristic Tokyo) or generic warehouses. Generally your task is to find all the enemies in the stage and kill them, then head to an extraction point to escape. The enemies themselves are cyborgs which use firearms and/or swords. Difficulty ranges between extremely easy to genuinely pretty difficult, and enemies will come at you from all directions so you constantly need to watch your back.

Movement is always a tricky area in VR games as it can make people motion sick very easily. Sairento gets around this by having 2 options for moving. Simple movement works like a teleport (so no movement is visible) and is designed for people easily susceptible to motion sickness. The full movement mode allows you to dash and jump. So far I haven't felt ill from it and it seems very well done. Jumping also gives you much more freedom and interesting ways of killing your enemies- you can even slide along the floor if you crouch while you're in mid-jump.

Weapons feel fluid and well-tracked, though I've ditched firearms for the most part and find dual wielding katanas to be the most satisfying. You can deflect bullets, charge energy shots and attack exactly as you want to. Want to jump at an enemy and slash them as you land? You can do it. Want to hit enemies in front and behind at the same time with separate swords? You can do it.

Briefly, there is also a crafting and loot element to the game- you can find relics which can be placed in your weapons (a bit like socketing in Diablo) and these give you various bonuses and allow you to find a playstyle that works for you.

The only downside I can think of with Sairento currently (other than lack of content, which is going to be addressed) is that all movement costs Focus and I found myself quite often running out of it which effectively means you can't move, aside from the small amount of Room Scale movement you can have. There are abilities to increase Focus regen but I personally don't think you should use Focus for short dashes.

Incredibly immersive game so far and I'm looking forward to seeing how it develops. Too many VR games are happy with what I can only describe as overglorified demos so it would be nice to see one come to fruition.

Tons of promise. A superb action game with a decent progression system, which rewards mobile, high-speed playstyles. A refreshing change from most shooters currently on the VR market which tend to rely heavily on cover.

With dual weilding, bullet time, melee combat and a simple but engaging loot system, there's enough content here even in the early stages of this game's development to justify reccomending this game to the vast majority of VR owners.

Sairento's mobility options feel very intuitive and feel extremely slick, which makes pulling off acrobatic manuvers such as double jumps, wallruns, dashes and even sliding simple and rewarding every time.

Optional trackpad locomotion means that Sairento is absolutely one of the best games currently on the market when it comes to movement, as you can freely explore the level without feeling rooted in place. Even without it, the emphasis on verticality and rapidly dashing between enemies makes the gameplay feel far more dynamic than most games.

There are a few rough edges which are understandable for a game that's early in development: Sound design is fairly minimalistic, with no enemy cues and very few ambient noises. Melee combat is functional but lacks presence and weight, and there's a lack of variety in environments and enemy types, but even with these issues it's a solid, entertaining game.

The devs seem to be putting a lot of effort into making the game as good as they can, so I'm very eager to see how far they take it. As it stands, Sairento is a very interesting and fun shooter that offers an experience that makes most of its rivals feel flat in comparison.
